elements.title: Captain John Purves and His Wife (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that according to art historian Margaretta M. Lovell, Captain John Purves and His Wife (pictured) reflects the late eighteenth century's turn toward companionate marriage?

elements.title: Spotlight (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that "Spotlight", the best-selling digital single in Chinese music history, saw its Douban rating drop from 10.0 to 3.2 less than two days after its release?

elements.title: Platigliole Glacier (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the melting of the Platigliole Glacier in Italy has revealed artefacts of the White War, including clothing and hay more than 100 years old?

elements.title: Rodney Parker (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that eleven years after serving as a Super Bowl usher, Rodney Parker came back to the game as a player?

elements.title: Alpha (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Shenseea almost named Alpha after her dead mother?

elements.title: Eli N. Evans (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Eli N. Evans authored three books about the culture and history of Jews in the American South?

elements.title: Palu (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the selection of Palu as capital of Palu Regency led to protests from the nearby town of Donggala, concerned they would lose out on economic development?

elements.title: Bronco Charlie Miller (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that elderly showman Bronco Charlie Miller would light matches, held in the mouths of Boy Scouts, using a 20-ft bull whip?
